titleStmt.title: A 1.11 Art. Seld. Pastedowns to the upper and lower board
Fragments in printed books

msIdentifier.idno: A 1.11 Art. Seld. (pastedowns to the upper and lower board)

msDesc.head: Corpus juris civilis: Institutiones Justiniani with the Glossa ordinaria of Accursius; English, late 13th or early 14th century

msItem.title: Institutes
msItem.note: with the Glossa ordinaria of Franciscus Accursius

Two complete leaves from the same manuscript, with part of book two of Justinian’s Institutiones, framed by the Glossa ordinaria of Franciscus Accursius (d. 1260). For Accursius and the Glossa ordinaria, see Dondorp and Schrage, pp. 23‒25.

Fragm. I (pasted to the upper board; originally a verso): Inst. 2.1.35‒41; Corpus iuris civilis, ed. Krüger and Mommsen, pp. 12‒13; framed by the corresponding Glossa ordinaria of Franciscus Accursius.
msItem.incipit: superuenerit et fundum uendicet de fructibus … ¶Is uero ad quem ususfructus fundi pertinet …
msItem.explicit: ¶Uendite uero res et tradite non aliter emptori adquiruntur: quam si is uenditori
msItem.incipit: agere. nec ad precium ut .J. de officio iudicis
msItem.explicit: teneri possunt. ut ff. de act. emp. lex iulia. ₵ offerri
msItem.note: Followed, at the foot of the page, by a five-line addition of a passage from the gloss omitted earlier: ad exiben. lex thesaurus. suo. iure directo ... rerum do. lex si is qui ₵ quod si creditor. ac.[ (from the gloss to Inst. 2.1.39).

Fragm. II (pasted to the lower board; originally a recto): Inst. 2.7.4‒8.2; Corpus iuris civilis, ed. Krüger and Mommsen, pp. 15‒16; framed by the Glossa ordinaria of Franciscus Accursius for 2.8. intro. ‒ 8.2.
msItem.incipit: serui secundum partem dominii quod nos difficimus [emended to diffiniuimus] accipiente. [red] Quibus licet uel non licet alienare. Accidit aliquando
msItem.explicit: dampno celebrata hoc permittat. conchi quo subsecuto: si et iudex pronun-
msItem.incipit: ntetur sicut alii dicuntur domini rerum pennarum ... corrigentes in duobus capitulis et in aliis non.
msItem.explicit: securitas. ut nec restitutio detur secus in predio alienato cum decreto et em

msItem.note: The gloss is that printed, with only minor variations, in the 1468 edition of Justinianus, Institutiones [with the Glossa ordinaria of Accursius], for which we have consulted Bod-Inc. J‒230.

Interlinear and occasional marginal glosses in several hands. The interlinear glosses, mostly in Fragm. II, and one marginal note are contemporary with the text hand, whereas an Isaiah quotation (5:12) and Latin verses (‘Pronaque cum spectant …’ (Ovid, Metamorphoses, 1.84‒87), and ‘Collige natura que perveniunt sine cura / Messes cultura lac lanum collige cura’, unidentified) in Fragm. I are in distinctive late-medieval English hands, most likely added after the leaf was used in this binding. The two-line note at the foot of Fragm. II (‘Versus [:] Mutuo dat nummos ..., with a definition of ‘Alienacio’), also in a distinctive English hand, may be an earlier addition. These hands are similar in character (although not identical) to those of the early 16th-century marginal notes that run throughout the two parts of the incunable Sammelband.
The leaves are incorrectly identified in Bod-Inc. I 91 (A-100) as Dig. 22.28 and Inst. 2.8.

supportDesc.extent:
2 complete leaves. 309 208
(Fragm. I)
309 204
(Fragm. II)
162 96
Main text block Intercolumnar space: 12 mm.
265 166
Text block including gloss
supportDesc.condition: Some staining, but generally in good condition and legible. Fragm. I appears to be complete. The left-hand margin of Fragm. II (approximately 4 mm), which formerly formed a hook round the last quire of the De animalibus, is now lost, with the result that in each line of the gloss the first few letters are missing. Only one side of each fragment is visible as the leaves remain pasted to the boards.

layoutDesc.layout: Text 34/35 written lines, Main text in 2 columns (43 mm, intercolumnar space 12 mm), framed by the surrounding gloss. Running heads in blue and red: ‘Ł’ on the verso (Fragm. I) and ‘II’ on the recto (Fragm. II). For the tradition of the textus inclusus in legal manuscripts of this period, see L’Engle and Gibbs, pp. 56‒57.
Gloss 76 (Fragm. I) and 66 (Fragm. II) written lines. 2 columns (6 or 7 lines of gloss above the text, 16 lines below in Fragm. I, 8 lines below in Fragm. II).

handDesc.handNote: A rather small Gothic book-hand of medium quality (Northern Textualis), possibly the work of two different scribes for the text and the gloss (as indicated, for example, by two forms of ‘box-a’). A smaller grade of script is employed for the gloss. English (as indicated, for example, by the letter ‘a’ in the gloss, which rises slightly above the headline: ex inf. Patricia Stirnemann). Datable to the later 13th or possibly early 14th century.

decoDesc.decoNote: A single two-line blue initial in Fragm. II, with red flourishing, accompanied by a red heading; alternating red and blue paraphs in the text.

accMat.p: Two incunable editions in chancery folio make up this volume:
1. Aristoteles, De animalibus. 88 fols. Venice: Bartholomaeus de Zanis, 9 Aug. 1498. (Bod-Inc. A‒392, ISTC ia00976000, GW 233).
2. Albertus Magnus, De animalibus. 261 fols. Venice: Johannes and Gregorius de Gregoriis, de Forlivio, 21 May 1495. (Bod-Inc. A‒100, ISTC ia00225000, GW 589).
Place of origin: Printed in Venice.
Binding: English (Cambridge). Contemporary blind-tooled brown calf over wooden boards, assigned by Oldham to the Cambridge Heavy Binder, active 1485-1505 (Oldham, pp. 18, 92‒94, with pl. xi).

1. John Sampson, 'Liber Joannis Sampson' on q6v of item 1; in view of the contemporary Cambridge binding probably the John Sampson who was Vice-Provost of King's College, Cambridge (d. 1517). See Bod-Inc. VI 2913.
2. John Selden (1584‒1654), with whose library the volume came to the Bodleian in 1659; listed in the catalogue of the Selden library (MS. Selden Supra 111, f. 44r). See Bod-Inc. VI 2915‒16.

recordHist.source: Description by Ruth Mullett & Nigel Palmer (May 2016)
